div.p:
—On Tuesday evening a meeting was
held at the London Mechanies’ Institution for the purpose of discussing
the desirability of instituting a further search for traces of Sir John
Franklin and his comrades. Dr King moved the first resolution,
“That the efforts hitherto made to discover traces of the Franklin
expedition having been wholly unsuccessful, a future search is im-
peratively required.” Dr King explained at some length his project
for a combined expedition by sea and land to the mouth of the Great
Fish River, and expressed his conviction that if such an undertaking
were confided to himself and Lieut. Bedford Pim, they would bring
to light some positive evidence of the fate of Franklin and his com-
panions. Dr King, in conclusion, read a letter from Baron Von
Humboldt to Lieut. Pim, of which the following is an extract: “How
could you for an instant doubt the satisfaction with which here in
Germany we receive the intelligence, though somewhat vague, of a
memorial presented to Lord Palmerston, endorsed by so many
illustrious names, announcing the hope of a new expedition directed
towards a point already determined upon. You should have seen the
lively and affecting interest excited both at Court and in the public
mind by your noble and courageous Siberian undertakings. After so
many generous sacrifices made by two nations of the same race already
in possession of objects pertaining to the shipwrecked mariners, and
having reduced the results to such narrow limits, how can you avoid
a last perilous effort (great undertakings are ever somewhat hazardous)
for the solution of this sad enigma? Geography and the physical
knowledge of our globe have been advanced by what has been already
gained; but there is a moral end to be attained, and in this under-
taking there is a sentimental interest excited by the consanguinity of
those you seek to rescue, ascending to a source above all science—an
interest which should be cherished in the breast of a nation—a senti-
ment at once ennobling and consolatory. P.S. What can you
anticipate from my support? You will smile at my ‘moral end,’
—at the ‘sentiment I would nourish in the breast of the people,’—
at my German sensibility; but I have still force enough to defend
myself, and you are at liberty to use these few lines in any way you
may find useful.” Lieut. Pim seconded the resolution, and detailed the
route by which he proposed to reach Dr King. Difficulties, no doubt,
would have to be encountered; but long experience in the Polar Seas
had considerably lessened the danger of the search; and his own
opinion was that it was only necessary to approach the Esquimaux
with a little circumspection, to extract from them the striking story
of our countrymen’s suffering, and to induce them to tell at what
village the survivors would be found. The resolution was carried
unanimously; and after a short discussion a motion was carried
approving of the plan suggested.
